 Well, I think it goes without saying that kids are going to better off under a mother AND father, where they can get the experiences, wisdom, etc. that both can give.  It is impossible to determine that a male-female couple is the most ideal set up for adoption and/or foster care, because there are too many other factors involved in the equation. Environment (neighborhood, neighbors, etc), extended family, income education, number of other siblings, schooling, family "values", etc., all play a part in how suitable a person or couple is at raising children.
 
 Ideally, it is the extended family (which may include relatives, neighbors and friends) that is the best for raising children, since it has a large enough support network.

 Do you think that gay people have no people of the opposite sex in their lives at all? Gay men have mothers, sisters, aunts, and female friends and relatives. Lesbian women have fathers, brothers, uncles and male friends and relatives. There are teachers and preachers and coaches and mentors. Plenty of men and women all over the place to be role models for kids. What there is a shortage of is homes for unwanted or orphaned kids who are not infants. I regularly check the list for my county - there generally around 100 kids waiting adoption. The foster list is much longer. Kids miss out when we worry about looking like the Cleavers. Singles and couples of all sorts can and do love kids.

Cut and paste
 However, hundreds of kids with gay parents have been run through the social science mill, poked, prodded, filled out endless questionnaires and interviewed at length. When all the studies published to date are taken individually or as a whole, the results are uniform:
 
 * There are no significant differences between kids with gay parents and kids with straight parents on a variety of psychological measures, including gender-roles, self-esteem, and more.
 * Kids with gay parents are no more likely than kids with straight parents to be gay themselves. Although in our opinion this begs the question, "so what if we were?"
 * Similarly, when all the studies of lesbian moms and gay dads are analyzed, there are few quantitative differences from their straight counterparts.
 * Research that has looked at the qualitative experiences of gay parents and their kids is scarce...although there are now a few books and a number of articles and shows that deal anecdotally with the experiences of gay parents and their kids. 
 
 http://www.colage.org/research/index.html

 So? My son has plenty of "father figures." He has my brother, my father, numberous cousins and a large extended family as well as our friends and his own. He isn't "weak" or "sissy" in any way. He's a good young man, with moral convictions (not religiously installed either, mind you), compassion, honesty and a healthy attitude towards fairness towards both genders. He participates in sports (high school varsity Football as well as others), plays MULTIPLE musical instruments, has a great girlfriend who's smart and funny and very sweet. 
 Is he suffering for not having his biological father in his life daily or even monthly? No. Not at all. He sees his father maybe once a year. But that's his father's choice. 
 If his father fell off the face of the Earth tomarrow, he would suffer no loss of male role models. His father just doesn't play that big a role in his life to begin with. But my son has PLENTY of other male role models to look up to. 
 Some straight, some gay, but all good men. 
 
 Something you just can't seem to get through your head is the fact that adopted/fostered children aren't only raised by their parents. There is almost always an extended network of family and friends who care for the child as well. 
 
 Oh, and I really hate to break it to you...BUT GAY MEN make Excelent adopted/foster parents as well!
JustineCredible

I am sure that it is good to have all those people in a childs life but I am sorry its not the same as a father...........Nothing can replace that......

 
 Sounds to me more like you have some unresolved absentee father issues.
jitobear

I am sure that it is good to have all those people in a childs life but I am sorry its not the same as a father...........Nothing can replace that......

 What exactly does that have to do with what I said? 
 
 I was making the observation that maybe you had an absentee father, not that you were an absentee father. Of course if you were that's really an issue you need to deal with, and here is not the forum for such. 
 
 What exactly does your daughter having a college degree and two kids have to do with a child raised in a home of only one gender parental figures? 
 Was your daughter raised by two women or two men? 
 Did you not have extended family, friends and/or neighbors as a support network? 
 Just because your daughter was raised in a home with one parent of each gender really proves nothing at all. Not one damned thing. 
 It doesn't prove that my son or Jito's son is any worse off than you daughter. Our children are considerabley YOUNGER than your daughter. I would hope like hell that neither of our kids were sexual active at their current ages. 
 My son is still in High School, jito's I think is even younger. 
 My son is only a sophomore, is taking ap (advanced placement) courses in physics and trig. He already knows where he wants to go for college and what career path he wants to take. 
 
 What does you flaunting your daughter, who is considerably older than our children prove? 
 
 Not one damned thing.

 I really have to agree with you there. But that's also has a lot to do with how I was raised and what my parents did for a living. My dad worked in Television in Chicago. When I was very young my dad was the director for Soul Train. When the Directors' Guilde went on strike, the kids walked the pickette lines for them. Before that he worked at another local station during the civil rights movement and the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Some of his best friends were members of the Black Panthers.
 Am I black, no. Is he, no. He's this lilly white guy from Canada, of all places. But I was definitely a product of the times when I was born and the environment in which I was raised.
